reviewText:
I have to say firstly i don't write reviews, but i felt i had to as this game is massively under rated.
So much has changed i'm glad i gave it another go.
I thought it had lost its way a while back but things have certainly changed for the better. Definitely one of the best sims out there atm,
Graphics are good, 3 screens looks good, a little optimization would help so fps are more stable, that said its not an issue, i am running it on ultra where possible and it only drops to 58 occasionally with vsync on. The 980's are coping nicely.
Sounds are very realistic and clear, surround is good.
The AI are the best in any racing sim right now.
The cars feel good, the feedback to the Fanatec Clubsport is excellent, FWD WTCC cars are spot on, that said the BMW is awesome, driven correctly it will stay with and often beat the FWD cars which can be tough on certain circuits.
Had a lot of online races and thoroughly enjoyed every one of them, just need to be able to host servers ourselves but the multiplayer clearly states alpha so i'm happy to be able to even race online right now.
There are a nice selection of tracks, would like to see some more from the UK but that's my preference.
I purchased the majority of my content while on sale, not sure i could justify the full price to be honest as it seems too expensive as it marketed as a FTP" game

All in, it's unfortunate that this is the economic model we are given. If there was a free to play element with perhaps a War Thunder style tech tree or something (Not sure how it would work but still) it would be possibly the pinnacle of racing games on steam.

Unfortunately what the end user is presented with is a game that would cost in excess of £150 to fully unlock with no option to earn any of the unlocks by actually playing the game.

It's a massive shame. I wish it wasn't like this. It was fun to play.

reviewText:
This game really does need a steering wheel / pedal set to get the best out of it. Controlling any of the cars with the keyboard is hard. A game controller might make things a bit easier, and the game does support mouse steering, but neither of these is ideal. The free to play content has some very high powered cars which make keyboard control even more difficult, which is one reason that a lot of players give up after a short time.

If you've got a wheel and pedals it's a different matter. I love it. The cars feel 'alive' - challenging and fun to drive. The AI is really solid, the sound is awesome and the graphics are nice too. A real gem - the ADAC GT Masters 2014 and DTM 2014 packs are simply brilliant and make for some seriously exciting racing against the AI.

It's good online too

reviewText:
Don't let people turn you away from this game if you really like to race. It is a very good simulation but there are some that would say otherwise due to not taking the time to get to know the physics model and the fact that the gas pedal has more positions than just nothing to floored.

Now thats not to say that this game doesn't have flaws. After all what games these days don't have a flaw here and there? The only big flaw for me is that the AI has vastly superiour grip to the player but you can get close with the right amount of tuning and the Devs are working on fixing that issue right now. Online races in this game are a real blast in Get Real mode but first I beg you to log practice time in this mode. Based on the multiplayer races I have seen lately people think that get real mode is going to be like driving a normal car in real life.

Now the problem with that kind of thinking is that the engines on these cars are made to go much faster than a normal car that you would drive daily so Get Real mode takes some practice but after you master it it is definately the best mode. Another thing the devs might add soon is an offline mode which will be great for unexpected times of internet outage since you would still be able to log some track time if you want.

In short yes this game has some flaws but so does every other game ever developed so if you really like racing give this a try. I mean its free so you've got nothing to lose except a little bit of time if you don't like the game but wouldn't you have burned that time gaming anyway?

reviewText:
So here I am writing a review for RaceRoom Racing Experience. So my first impressions of the game are good, in terms of gameplay the sounds are immaculate and very realistic. The force feedback you recieve through the wheel are really good and racing is challenging especially in multiplayer.

Pros:

-Great Sounds
-Great Force Feedback
-Car models look good
-Racing is a challenge and you feel like you are in a real car
-Has support for all controllers (wheels and joysticks and controllers)
-You can make your own overlay for a race and broadcast it live
-If you drive the wrong way you ghost meaning that trolls cannot crash you out using a head on collision
-Physics and handling are very realistic
-Different modes: Novice, Amateur and Realistic
-Decent Graphics and fps with support for high end and low end spec computers
-Good default overlay
-So many things that can be changed in settings

Cons:

-The free mode only comes with 3 (I think) car series and 2 (I think) tracks
-No pit crew/garage interior
-No Career mode where you can make your own racer and have any sort of car improvement
-Mirror visibility is not great and hard to depict cars until they are too close to try and defend

I realise this game is still in development and i am looking forward to more content but I think sector3 studios have done a fantastic job on this game so its a thumbs up from me.

Therefore I would rate it 9/10 as there could be a few things that could be improved (like adding some more free dlc etc.) but it surprised me with how good the gameplay was.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After almost two years of floaty physics, stuttering, bad communication, outrageous prices and lack of racing, R3E is finally turning around.

Regular sales bring the content to more sensible prices, the force feedback has been tightened up to give better information about the car, the physics are more precise and very detailed and the setup makes a big difference. Most of the racing right now is in the DTM series, but the challenges are fun and allow you to try several cars and tracks without paying a dime.

Visually, it's a bit bright and bold, but the environments look good and clear. Visibility and details are high, and the shadows passing on the dashboard look really nice. The performance on High settings with 8x AA with a 750ti is 60 fps when there's only one car, so I think the optimization is pretty good as well.

The sounds are probably the best you'll hear in a racing game, whether it's the samples themselves or just the richness of the chassis squeaking, the transmission, the tires, etc. Everything is there and sounds great. No other game comes close.

The interface is still complex and confusing, and some options are only available from the main menu. The FFB is very adjustable, but the settings are not explained much, so it takes a lot of fiddling to get everything right. For me, that means G25 and TH8RS. The modern cars don't default to auto-clutch, which is lame.

Because the game looks and sound so good, and now that the FFB is finally letting the new and tighter physics shine through,  Raceroom is becoming a killer racing game. I never thought it could be possible, but out of this could arise a GTR3 people have hoped for. In the meantime, doing time trials, challenges and racing in DTM is a lot of fun.

To newcomers: skip the free content and go straight for the competitions, this is where the higher quality content is. It cycles through cars and tracks regularly, so you can sample stuff until you find what you like. The freebies are still the old wobbly garbage from 2012, it seems. I think everything will be updated over time.

reviewText:
My Prefered choice of racing sim 8/10

had plenty of experience in racing sims over the years .
competed in hindreds of online leagues and comps

Raceroom is worth checking out,its free to play  but limited to a couple of tracks and car models
Other stuff you can buy in the store
i bought the euro and yank tracks and GT2 and GT3 series cars for around 20usd in game store
Steam also sells pack add ons

So,Pricing is reasonable,the Bathurst track was 3 bucks.
i challenge anyone to find a better representation of mount panorama in a sim,simply wonderful.

Online play is good with plenty of options for hosting a Dserver or just joining a league race
Simbin struggled with connection problems years ago but it seems that it is just a bad memory now.however the occasional server update or maintenance may get in the way on the rare occasion

European racing is the core of this  sim and you are spoiled for choices of series available
Physics and feel ,the sounds and the visuals make this the better sim for my taste.

Unlike rFactor,its not a game where you must hunt for mods and racing series to play something you like or need
buy what you want and add more as required in the easy to see and use in game store
you can even test drive cars before you buy them.very cool

the car models are painstakingly copied from the real thing,the Porsche GT2 is simply the best version of the car in any sim and that goes for most of the other cars i have bought.

Stats and laptimes etc are all recorded and you can challenge other players in the leaderboard shoot outs for fame and glory

If you liked GTR1,2 and GT Legends,race07 etc,this sim will feel right at home.

if i had one minor complaint it would be damage modeling graphics could be improved,cars can take an atonishing impact and still drive away,most times.i understand why they chose this model.its designed to keep you racing after a heavy spin.so this may detract from the hardcore simmer,but,cars still break or fail so its not so bad.
its about resource management id suggest,why waste too much time on what a car looks like when it hits the wall and 300kmh and is out of the race, concentrate on the racing performance instead.

8/10

reviewText: I have no idea why there are so many negative reviews.  Nevertheless, the reviews were so bad about a year ago that I didn't touch it.  So I did wait until Dec 2015 to try it out after all the patches and changes that seemed to make it worth buying.  I race in iRacing, PCars, Assetto Corsa, FM, FH, and now RaceRoom.  The graphics inside the cockpit and looking out to the opponents is probably the best among these sims providing you have a decent PC and can max out the graphics.  I give it a 9.5/10 for graphics.  The physics are also very good since you can adjust many settings in the FFB.  So if you make a few adjustments, then I would easily say 9/10 on phyiscs.  And with all the adjustments you get for the feel, then nearly a perfect.    The gameplay is focused on DTM and GT3 in my opinion and that is pretty much why I bought it.  No other sims have anything really in the DTM class although I am hoping PCars gets into DTM more.  So if you like DTM, I can tell you this is the best sim for DTM.  I haven't had any issues at all and have to say the negative onslaught this game gets is just not accurate.  But there seems to be a few issues.  Like with the fuel and tire wear set to real, they don't seem to ever go down.  It's 100% all the time so I think that is a bug.  And the AI is annoying until you learn how to avoid them.  But this is one of the best sims out there in my opinion, especially DTM and GT3.  I just don't understand how people can spend 15 min on a game and slam the heck out of it.  Their connectivity issues and setup is more than likely their own setup problem.  Yes, it needs a little help with car setups too like adding tire pressure...lol  But the game feels and looks excellent,  It's worth the money for DTM for sure.\n\nUpdate: 4/30/2016 - RaceRoom is Awesome!  I've waited a month after the 3/31/2016 update that massively improved the GT3 and Prototype physics.  The new physics and new FFB settings, new car setup, especially for GT3, ADAC GT Masters, DTM, and the new Audi P1 along with Nordschleife puts this sim to the stellar level in my opinion.  In addition, the fuel and tire wear now works finally.  Neverthelesss, the new FFB meter to check for clipping is very nice.  I am very critical of physics and so you know where I am coming from, Assetto Corsa and iRacing have the top slot with PCars a close second.  Race Room was just behind PCars.  Unfortunately, Forza just doesn't have the physics at these levels, e.g. you cannot feel the rubber on the road and utilze braking to control the cornering accurately in Forza Motorsport at least yet.  So Forza is last in the physics ranking among all these.  But I am now putting RaceRoom up there at the Assetto Corsa and iRacing level.  I am at the point of saying the physics in Race Room, at least for the DTM, ADAC, GT3 and Prototype classes, is possibly even better than Assetto Corsa and iRacing.  The sound in Race Room is also stellar if not the best among the aformentioned sims and I am not even using 7.1 yet just stereo.  Race Room does not get the recognition it deserves....another point is I am astonished it's onlyh using DX9c where all the others I've mentioned are on DX11 or even DX12.  So it blows me away they are getting this level of crisp graphics viewing the opponents cars and interior that they do....congrats Race Room for pulling that off.

reviewText: I don't often review games (or anything else), but with all the thumbs down this has gotten I decided it needed my input.  First let me say that I raced real cars for 9 years on both ovals and road courses. I've also sim raced on and off since about 1992.  I'm not an expert on sim racing, but I've tried most of the major players and R3E is among the very best -- I find the physics to be superb, at least when used with a good wheel and pedals.  I can't comment on how it plays on kb, controller or anything else and frankly I don't care.\n\nOne of the problems with sim racing is how to represent the loss of traction that one *feels* in the real world through balance, touch and seat of the pants. A common perception in the sim world is that a game is realistic when it is very difficult, but the real world isn't like that -- vehicles only get very difficult close to the limit.  I think R3E does an admirable job of balancing difficulty without crossing the line into arcade".  Is it better than iRacing or Assetto Corsa? I don't know....that's really on a car-by-car basis for me
date: but some of them are better and none that I've driven are really bad (and even iRacing has had some stinkers).\n\nI also don't think the "free to play" system is that bad.  You can have some great fun without ever buying anything!  Certain track and car combinations are always available (for free!) in the "competitions".  These are really just hot-lap contests
recommended: but they are fun and you get to try out the content.....and it is still free.  Raceroom is expensive if you buy all the DLC
hoursPlayed: but I just don't see a need for that -- just buy whatever series you want to race in
voteText:
and if you are really cheap just by one car in each class.  Either way it is still a lot cheaper than iRacing.

The downsides of Raceroom:

-the severs are usually empty
helpfulPercent: but then I don't use this for online racing.\n- the AI can be a bit aggressive
votesHelpful: but are otherwise pretty good.\n-can't save setups (really????).  I've heard this is coming in the next update"

reviewText:
...And I thought Gran Turismo was brutal (S-Class License in that game was not easy to obtain, BTW. Fortunately, not a requirement in this one. I also beat GT3 and most of GT4. So I'm familiar with the overall brutality of these simulators.). Then again, it's been ages since I last played a simulation racing game (At least 5 years worth of rust on me); and now with more accurate simulation settings as such, ugh. Made a decent personal time on Get Real (without shattering my car or breaking the engine), but I needed Novice to get a better handle of when to brake overall for next time (I can survive, at least, but I'm nowhere near leaderboard-ready yet at time of post). You botch the braking anywhere (especially blind corners and chicanes), and you can mess up your entire lap, or go off course, or 180-1080 your car, and invalidate your lap (no shortcutting like I used to in GT and NFS; also no more using other cars as guardrails on certain turns either :( ).

Not stopping me from playing this more, and maybe getting an expansion pack or two to have more cars to drive with and more tracks to drive on. However, as precise I can get with a keyboard, I lack pressure sensitivity in order to draw a bead more precisely; so my skills are a tad biased (better with a gamepad for these kinds of games). +20.5 seconds (1:43.334 on a track) from 1st place (Leaderboards, that is) is not good enough for me. I gotta shave off more time... If I can clear +10 seconds from 1st, then I'll be a happier driver. +5, and I'll be impressed with myself. This game is not easy, because it's less game, and more simulator. The physics are quite familiar and rather unforgiving (like reality would be), especially in Get Real (and that mode also permits fine-tuning your car's aerodynamics, gear-shift ratios, and just about everything else under the hood; and tire wear is also quite unforgiving too, so keep those in check along with your fuel). If you seek a casual racing experience, I suggest a different game, lest you want to lose some keyboards or controllers in frustration. It can become casual, however, if you're a pro at this kind of stuff.

Been awhile since I've had such a detailed racing experience, so thumbs up on bringing back my memories of Gran Turismo (In due time, I'll see you guys on the Nürburgring Course (up to 10 minutes per-lap, and that's with skill and a good car; BIIIG Course (28.265 km long). An ultimate test for drivers, both skill and endurance. Look it up. In GT4, my best time was about 9 minutes, or slightly less than that, and even so, I had difficulties there.)). However, only other (personal) setback is that your real name is visible (security and such, I guess). Just a friendly heads-up for anyone else that feels like crashing into walls and cars non-stop (eg- signing up to play). The heads-up is also for those that would end up broadcasting, and still want to remain anonymous; I suggest going somewhere else for privacy while broadcasting publicly.

I can imagine how this will play with Oculus support. Speaking of which, the graphics are 10/10; runs smoothly with high settings, even for older machines like mine, and the graphics are a beauty overall; the sound is also rather pretty too, for you gearheads. If you want an immersive driving experience, or want to relive an A-Spec GT experience, I recommend this. Plus, it's free to play. Despite the 10GB download (mostly locked content), what's not to love? I suggest building some experience and skill before investing in any new cars/tracks/DLC packs. At least, know you can handle it first, before burning your money on this, and then giving it a negative review from poor judgement user-side.

See you on the leaderboards, and by chance, on the tracks.

reviewText:
I didn't like R3E for a while and avoided purchasing any of the content but this game has come a long ways and Sector3 Studios has really changed the game around.

First off the free to play portion of the game is more like a demo/base portion of the game. There are around 5 free cars and 2 tracks. This lets you try the game out and see if you like it. You purchase content (cars, tracks, packs, and experiences) based on what you want. You don't have to buy everything and most people don't.

The packs are always discounted and go on sale frequently. Any content you have also gets discounted from packs and experiences.

Experiences are basically full games that run through the base game of Raceroom. (So the DTM and ADAC GT experiences.)

All the content I own I got on sale and I got DTM 2014 and WTC 2013 for free! I won these through the free competitions that are held in Raceroom. They cycle through these competitions around each month. Some are just for bragging rights and some have rewards such as the in game currency (VRP), game content, or even real race tickets.

I have all the other big sims and I like raceroom for providing content that the other don't and also providing real race series with the tracks they race on. You can compete on the leaderboards with real race drivers in the DTM and ADAC GT series and they even host races with them from time to time.

I definitely recommend trying it out and seeing if you like it. If you do, I suggest waiting for one of the sales either through raceroom or on steam, like the summer sale :).

reviewText:
I am a sim racer since the good old C64 REVS. Since that year I drove nearly every race sim on the market.

To make it short: Race Room Experience is definitely the one available.
Its the feeling of the game: No other race game has such a good force feedback and sound.
The AI is very good.

Maybe other title have better graphics (project cars), but this one just feels great.
Racing RRE is such a great experience. After a race with a good FFB wheel (like CSW 2), you are completely done.
Its so heavy to feel the road and the opponents and hear the best racing sound on the market.

Give it a try, even with the free version you can have A LOT OF FUN.

Their is so many high quality content available that every race sim fan is happy.

My personal favorites are: DTM 1992, Group C cars and Brands Hatch and Salzburgring.

reviewText:
Absolutely love race room racing experience. Along with Assetto Corsa, these are the driving sims I have been looking for. I have always played driving games like Forza, Grid, F1, NFS & various Rally games on consoles then recently got Project cars. At first I really liked Project Cars graphics, Car selection and tracks selection but in my opinion the games play ability was my problem. I tried playing it with an Xbox controller which I found very frustrating and no fun at all. I was told to buy a steering wheel for the ultimate experience. So after a couple of months and much frustration, I said what the hell & bought a £270 steering wheel which is compatible with Xbox and PC. Project Cars was actually much better but I just did not like the game play and car feel on track. As my new steering wheel was also PC compatible I started to look for driving sims on Steam. This is where I found Race Rooms. It was a breath of fresh air. At first, I thought it can't be any good if it's free but I wanted to test my steering wheel out so I downloaded it. OMG! Fell in love straight away. This was the game I was looking for. Excellent graphics, great car choice, great tracks, easy to operate and fantastic game play. No more dodgy handling like Project Cars.

To enjoy this game to the max, you need a good steering wheel with force feedback.
A couple of months ago I was a bit reluctant to buy a wheel for so much money and was concerned about where to set it up. Anyway I gave in and bought one from Amazon and converted my home office. Best thing I have ever done for gaming. I haven't touched my Xbox One console in months. Recently I have even bought Assetto Corsa too. These are my best racing sims at present which I feel comfortable with and can control on the track.

I have bought all the tracks and several car packs. On occasions there are weekend discount deals which can save you money. Also, buy VRP credit from Race Room website direct because you get more VRP then buying add-ons directly from Steam.

Also, you MUST have Internet connection to play this game.

Anyway, I would defiantly recommend this game with a good steering wheel with force feed back and a nice sound setup. No sim game is perfect out there right now because we all like and want different experiences. One mans meat is another mans gravy!

reviewText:
What is Raceroom?Raceroom is in basic english a Raceing Simulator (not meant to be sarcastic).
This game is a all round good game, whilst only playing abit on this account most of my testing has been on my games review account (So dont start complaining that 'YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED ENOUGH TO WRITE A REVEIW' Because i have played around 10 hours altogether.)
This game is for people that dont want to spend £30 pounds on a racing game and play it evry once in a while, it offers a range of tracks and cars of the less known popular series, you may still end up paying £55 if you really enjoy this game.

The graphics of this game is good, while this game is 2 years old, my card (which is 5 years old) handles the game pretty well, the shadows are nice with the options to change the day setting which increases or decrease shadows. theres nothing else i can say about this ecept download the game and see for yourself.

in concluesion while this game is no project cars it comes close to it, if you are getting started in racing sims and you want to get a feel of what they are like then this is a good game for it otherwise  find another game to make it easier for you

reviewText:
Alot of reviews from people that won't give this game much time - Granted, I spent a good while getting the graphics and feeling (FFB etc) right but you will love it once you find that sweet spot. I find the physics of every car much more alive and engaging than similar vehicles on say, Project Cars or Assetto Corsa, with the force feedback (Using a G27) and the sounds being top notch. Easily the best of any racing sim IMO.

The mix of content is fantastic and the track list is a brilliant! - A load of tracks you actually want to drive, not a load of soul-less modern build tracks. Not many games can boast the opportunity to jump from a mental super tuned Zakspeed Capri, to a 2014 WTCC Lada, to a BMW Z4 GT3 then in to a 1992 Audi Quattro DTM. And then choose to take each either up a hillclimb, round Bathurst or to Indianapolis!

And the graphics, once dialled up are great. I run a GTX970 and that runs everything maxed. Yet while you can see its a game, everything looks very real.

The whole, 'free to play, but each thing costs extra, so you end up spending a tone if you get in to it', idea sucks. But with the prices being no so bad, it could be worst. I could be in to iRacing.

Give it a try. Buy some decent content and let the game develop over time as you get in to it and you will love it. The Sector3 forum is a great place to check up on what to expect in future releases aswell and what the team are working on - plus, if you don't like something, post it on there and they will have a look and you never know, they could sort it more to your liking.

reviewText:
Picked this up since it was free, figured I'd give it a try. First night playing, it was ok. The graphics are good. The physics seem good while providing a challenging driving experience. Although it did take me another day to get my FFB sorted. There really is no explanation for what some of the settings do. (or a short rather canned one)

Once I got my FFB dialed in, the game/sim really started to shine. I use the Logitech G27 with pedals and H-shifter. A wheel really is the preferred way to get the best experience, though I'm sure there are a handful of controller users out there who can rip it up pretty good.

The sounds really are pretty amazing. Especially when you start to drive different cars. Considering I've got 12 hours and 128 laps under my belt in one weekend, its safe to say I'm hooked.

If the devs can continue in the right direction with development, R3E has a lot of potential to be great! And don't be turned off by paid content until you at least try the free stuff. Other racing sim organizations (not mentioning any names) do the same thing.

=====Update 02/13/2015======

After 1100+ laps and over 2 days of total in game time I can say I'm still hooked. The most recent update Feb 2015 improved the AI and optimized the graphics. Dedicated servers are coming soon. I believe this year which will open up online racing leagues.

I own almost all the cars. All tracks and all packs but the hill climb. Yes a little pricey, but worth it IMO. The devs stay in constant contact with the community which is more than I can say for other games/sims. New tracks and cars are still in the works, the most recent upcoming new track, Sonoma and the Cadillac CTS VR coupe to be released soon as paid content. R3E has only gotten better since I've been playing it and it was pretty good when I started with it anyway.

R3E is definitely to be taken seriously among other race sims currently on the market.

reviewText:
Game looks great but personally I could not get it working with my Logitech GeForce Pro steering wheel. I was like a drunk driver, all over the track. Frame drops and other issus on start of race didn't help.

Maye it's the wheel as I see other people mention the Logitech setups are an issue. I just don't want to spend hrs setting up a wheel for each car I want to use.

The grass / track edges seem suck you in. Is that considered realism? I know many games will punish for cutting corners and it should be slippy on the throttle, but should you get sucked into the barrier?

reviewText:
What is Raceroom?Raceroom is in basic english a Raceing Simulator (not meant to be sarcastic).
This game is a all round good game, whilst only playing abit on this account most of my testing has been on my games review account (So dont start complaining that 'YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED ENOUGH TO WRITE A REVEIW' Because i have played around 10 hours altogether.)
This game is for people that dont want to spend £30 pounds on a racing game and play it evry once in a while, it offers a range of tracks and cars of the less known popular series, you may still end up paying £55 if you really enjoy this game.
If you are just getting into racing games, then this game  ISN'T FOR YOU (its like that for a reason), while people wont go out there and then to buy a game wheel and pedels, THIS GAME HATE KEYBOARD AND MOUSE AND STANDARD XBOX OR PLAYSTATION CONTROLLERS (that is also meant to be like that), after many failing attemps of trying to play this game i came to the concluesion to go to my local maplin store and buy some extra peripherals (aka wheel and pedels) i saw a massive improve of how many crashes i was getting.
The graphics of this game is good, while this game is 2 years old, my card (which is 5 years old) handles the game pretty well, the shadows are nice with the options to change the day setting which increases or decrease shadows. theres nothing else i can say about this ecept download the game and see for yourself.

in concluesion while this game is no project cars it comes close to it, if you are getting started in racing sims and you want to get a feel of what they are like then this is a good game for it otherwise  find another game to make it easier for you

i hope this helped in if the game is for you, if it did leave a thumbs up, if it didnt leave a thumbs down and if you think it was funny well Press the funny button.

reviewText:
This review has to be a very mixed bag. First off let me say I've been with this game from the start. From closed beta till now. I've seen it go from meh.. to a very decent game. Probably one of the best racing titles I've ever played. I always knew that if anybody could get a racing title right it would be these guys. It has the possibilites of blowing GTR 2 out of the water. Yes it could be that good!
However there are some very serious issues here. One is the pitstops. Flat after the Oct. 20 patch they don't work. I understand that pitsops in custom championships are coming and that's okay. They weren't originally advertsied to begin with after all. I can live with that. Impatiently but I'll live till then. However it's the broken pitsops in ADAC 2014 experience and DTM 2014 experience that upset me. Can't say about DTM 2015 as I don't own it and from the looks of it I may never. Working pitstops were advertised for the DTM and ADAC 2014 cars. Heck I owned the DTM 2013. It was the only reason to buy the newer set.

In ADAC 2014 the player's car drives straight through the pits without stopping. Resulting in disqualification for not stopping. In DTM 2014 your car stops but the pit doesn't seem to count. You guessed it resulting in your disqualification. These were advertised features. We have to assume they had this worked out before the advertised it , right? Guess not!

There are many other issues and to their credit they working on them. As the recent hotfix suggests but it's not enough. One main quirk if you decide to step into this game, is BEWARE THE PATCHES! They generally break twice as much as they fix. One over the summer brought the whole fool game down. In it's current state I couldn't recommend this game unless you are very patient. And it will be tested, trust me! It is a near brilliant racing title with lot's of racing fun though and if and only if you're willing to hang with it you will love it and hate it and love it and hate it.... You get the picture. I gave this title a thumbs up because it doesn't totally deserve a thumbs down! However you have been warned!

As for the 503 errors that everyone is experiencing. I can't say as mine thankfully have been limited. I must be living right or lucky. Also I need to add that I play only single player not multiplayer. So my review can't address any issues there as I haven't seen them. I really would like to give this game a thumbs sideways but can't. Hence the thumbs up.

reviewText:
Alot of reviews from people that won't give this game much time - Granted, I spent a good while getting the graphics and feeling (FFB etc) right but you will love it once you find that sweet spot. I find the physics of every car much more alive and engaging than similar vehicles on say, Project Cars or Assetto Corsa, with the force feedback (Using a G27) and the sounds being top notch. Easily the best of any racing sim IMO.

The mix of content is fantastic and the track list is a brilliant! - A load of tracks you actually want to drive, not a load of soul-less modern build tracks. Not many games can boast the opportunity to jump from a mental super tuned Zakspeed Capri, to a 2014 WTCC Lada, to a BMW Z4 GT3 then in to a 1992 Audi Quattro DTM. And then choose to take each either up a hillclimb, round Bathurst or to Indianapolis!

And the graphics, once dialled up are great. I run a GTX970 and that runs everything maxed. Yet while you can see its a game, everything looks very real.

The whole, 'free to play, but each thing costs extra, so you end up spending a tone if you get in to it', idea sucks. But with the prices being no so bad, it could be worst. I could be in to iRacing.

Give it a try. Buy some decent content and let the game develop over time as you get in to it and you will love it. The Sector3 forum is a great place to check up on what to expect in future releases aswell and what the team are working on - plus, if you don't like something, post it on there and they will have a look and you never know, they could sort it more to your liking.

reviewText:
I tried the game when launched 2 years ago and sure it has been seriously enhanced and optimized.
Outstanding sensations, Sound environnement, realism and Force Feedback feeling.
Playing on a 3 screens setup (5760*1080 / R9-290X / i7 4930k)  with G25 (DIY piston brake mod)
Stable game, no bugs so far, but FrameRate could be better or maybe i miss something in options.

Unfortunately the game has serious lacks like tire choice, temperature, setups saving, ...
So i don't know if i recommend or not.
As a realism-addict-gamer i would say YES YES YES : the sensations you get when you manage to drive a fast car in this simulator are just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic.
As a customer i would say NO : i'm seriously disappointed about many obvious lacks in the simulation, keeping in mind the money you need to spend to own decent car and tracks choices to practice and challenge.

But i could say same thing about our IRL cars: webcams, USB, SDcard etc are cheap and already old stuff from around 2000... so why aren't they supplied by default on every car in the market by then ?
Why do we still have to pay hundreds of euros to get that options on a 10-20.000 euros product ?

By the way you can drive some car and tracks FOR FREE INFINITELY !!
So no surprise if you buy it.

I just played 20h and i would already say it did worth the euros :)

reviewText: This is a Fantastic racing simulator. Very good graphics and over all game play. Be warned for those looking for an arcade like racing game because this is not the game for you then. reviewText: This is by far the best game Simbin have produced. The physics are spot-on, and, aside from a few licensing issues with the RUF brand and a few iconic tracks which are currently lacking (though I'm assured they're coming soon), this is a very complete game. I bought into this during the alpha stage when I was taken aback by the graphics and attention to detail in their fictional Raceroom track, and I haven't once regretted it. I think the likes of Assetto Corsa and Project Cars can only be substantially better by having a better selection of road-going cars and the Nordschleife, available as standard.

reviewText:
Terrific racing sim. Considering it's (apparently) not the final product, it's a beautiful game with some incredibly well-modelled cars with fun handling and great sound. The price of the addons is more than reasonable, in my opinion. My favourite pack so far has been the DTM 1992 car pack; the cars are just ludicrous fun.

Bear in mind that online multiplayer is fairly sparse. Sometimes you won't find any games for any of the car packs you own (aside from the free content), which is a shame. However - and this is a rarity in sim racing games - the AI provide a serious challenge and can often be more fun than racing online.

Download this game, buy the DTM 1992 pack and race on!

reviewText:
Free to Play Racing Sim where you pay for what you want.
For some reason this is enough to give the game a negative review. Not me.

This game has the best sounding cars I have ever heard in a video game. Period. Nothing else even comes close.
It also has outstanding forcefeedback, a big community, and accurate simulation. The AI is pretty good, it's very agressive though. It seems to be a bit dynamic.

I can't get enough of it. There's also a lot of real racing drivers that play this game which is pretty cool. It was, and wasn't, surprising to see Mike Rockenfeller at the top of the leaderboards for a few tracks.

If you like motorsport and have a racing wheel this is a must play. It's FREE, there's a few tracks you can try and you can test drive every car in the game for free, along with a handful you get for free. It's worth your time and if you don't like it there's no loss. You don't have to pay a cent.

reviewText: Overall, I like this game. I, to be honest, expected something along the lines of Forza or Grand Torismo standards, but in my eyes, it met a fraction of those standards. I have to admit though, this is a very nice and sharp looking game when it's on it's highest settings (it set mine to the highest setting because my computer is very powerful). I am very fond of how many cars there are in the game and I love how each and every one of them has their own different sound. Although i'm not a car expert, if fact I don't really know much about cars in the first place....but I still wanted to try this game as I have heard it looked amazing and was a very good free to play game. They were right. Although this game has a lot of good stuff about it, I feel it has quite a lot of negative stuff about it. To start off, I noticed how there was a MAJOR lack of music unlike Forza or Grand Torismo or most racing games combined. This really annoys me because I feel that the music can bring a certain video game to life (ex: Saints Row 3, I actually got hooked on it because I started listening to it's soundtrack and just fell in love). I also didn't like how a good 75% of controls are unbinded at default, which I don't know if that's because the developers just wanted to let the player bind them his/herself or because they were just too lazy. Another problem is with every single car. What I noticed is how they all fail to break especially on very hard turns. I always find myself in 5-6th gear and then a very hard turn comes and I slow down, but I slow down enough that i'm still in 3rd-4th gear which doesn't help with the turn (I stop nearly 2 seconds before the actual turn). This is also a problem because I don't know if I properly binded a key; handbrake. I binded it to space (it shows I binded it correctly in the settings, but i'm just not sure) and when I press space while the car is just rolling, nothing happens. If I use it when i'm turning, slight to nothing really happens. In most case senarios I feel it does virtually nothing, when compared to other racing games where the handbrake is vital to the game. Handbrake wasn't even pre-binded when I started the game. Set aside all the negative stuff about the game, I would like to focus on the positive stuff in the game. What I think I enjoy the most about this is how it's actually more of a formula one racing game as you don't see day-to-day cars in the game like Forza. I personally love the formula one cars because they always give me a sence of how it would really feel if I was in one. With a computer so heavily powered and with a game that looks so amazing as this one does, they make up well to fulfill what I like most about formula one cars. I also like how there are LOTS of cars and tracks to choose from (there aren't many default and free tracks and cars, but there are a TON of paid tracks and cars). Although I don't have a lot of time under my belt playing the game, I can see it will turn out to be a very well made game. 7.9/10

reviewText:
I got into R3E many months ago, and while my initial thoughts were negative, I opted to wait and see where SimBin (at the time) were going to go with this title especially as a fan of their earlier titles primarily Race 07 and GTR 2.

While initially it suffered from a stagnant development period, the new Sector3 and their current contributions have vastly improved this title to become my now go-to racing sim, with vast improvements in the areas of physics, force feedback, single player and multi-player and the constant rate new content is pushed out.

While graphics are impressive, other simulators such as Assetto Corsa or Project Cars lead in this area, not to say that Sector3 have done an outstanding job on their engine with impressive HDR, bloom and dynamic lighting effect. SimBin/Sector3 has always been a leader in bringing the driver the most realistic sound experience in all their titles, and this continues with R3E.

With the last major update, Sector3 have done a major overhaul of the force feedback system. Their track developers have developed a new technology to improve the presentation and feedback of their track’s road surface utilising data from telemetry to create a highly dense road surface that features small bumps and imperfections in the surface the increases the quality of the force feedback immensely.

AI does leave plenty of room for improvement, while R3E supposably utilises an “Adaptive AI”, I find many times, AI will run up the back of you like a solid lead block, causing a frustrating racing experience at the best of times with little to no effect on themselves.

Content is plentiful, with a range of cars and tracks with new content currently added recently including the ADAC 2013 GT Masters Pack and the WTCC 2013 Pack including tracks as part of each package. Still, the biggest question mark is the pricing system, while I have noticed and taken advantage of the pack discounts, standard pricing is on the expensive side. I personally would advise to hold off for specials or car packs prior to purchasing content if you consider yourself the collector, or buy one car in each class as needed. With the new inclusion of the new “Test Drive” feature, you will be able to make a sound decision prior to purchase regardless of the price.

As a free to play game, this title is worth the time to experience the improvements that Sector3 have made to bring this sim up to the standard that many sim racers will look for. If you're willing to part with your cash to race new cars on new tracks, then you will enjoy a race or two, whether its a against the AI, online multiplayer with friends, or a quick hotlapping session.

reviewText:
Its fun, you can use controller for this and it is very sharp and visually pleasing. However, the biggest problem is you can only get so far before you realize you must pay alot of money for new car, vinyl and track. There is no earn yourself a new ride with dedication and racking podium finishs. you spend the money just to race with new vehicle or tackle a different that was not already given to you. if you hate to pay-to-play... please stay away from this game it is no for you.

Not to be recommended to the Need for Speed (of any kind) / arcad'ee kids. If you were looking for alternative to Forza Motorsports on Xbox or an answer to Playstation's Gran Turismo, u may survive. This games mechanics and handling is similar to the console sim racers, but this PC sim is way much more serious then the console racers. this serious racing sim has a massive leaderboard filled with nothing but competitive times that other user across the world have placed. it more fun to race against ur friends times then some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pro race driver from Germany. it will be a pain in the ♥♥♥ if u hoped to be immersed in the game.

Again, the controls are solid, the game is sharp and presentable. but the pay to play more will most definitely kill your good vibes.

I tried almost every simulation outh there including iRacing , and i was excited for a new simbin title , cuz im a fan of simbim from way back with GT legends and GTR/GTR2 , so i was expecting a good sim, insted i got some Acrila cars that u can not get used to , just like iRacing , u cant feel the road , u can master a track but u cant master the grip, its just unconected... no way neer GTR ad GTlegends and Race07...i dont care  about graphics so thats my opinion on phisics and engine, a big fail from me , but i understand they wanna make it more fun and driver frendly but in there aprouch the have missed me .

Now a little bit of a content rewiev
Its not a free game , its a demo, if u want a game with content u have to buy it and its not cheep, i hate it , its like Star citizen , selling u a model of something and pricing it not as much as star citizen but still, its a 3D model, and when 10 000 ppl buy it u end u with 50 000euros in cash, does it cost that much to designe a 3D model of a car, NO, so what is it , a rip off is what it is , they dont want to make a game, thats why u cant play it standalone with no internet conection, they wann sell stuff like Star citizen cuz they have seen the amoun of money SC earned robing off kids with money, Im OK with that , rip off all kids with money i couldnt care less, but u wont get it from me , i want a racing simulation , that will work even if my internet connection is down, i want to pay for a game not a car or a track. I couldnt care less what tracks name is , or what car am i driving , as long as its a nice track and a good car phisics ,so i play would play rFactor with unlicensed cars and track that work good rather then pay 200e for RaceRoom that has all licensed cars that u can not feal and have to pay for a door panel and tyers .. thats what it boilds down too, they would sell i virtual wheels and windshields if they could but they cant so they sell cars and tracks, im not in too that, so what are the alternatives

Alternatives

So thats my review , boils down too if u have money there is no reason not to try to buy content, but if u suport financial models like that u will end up paying for wind shields ,rims and car skins, maybe even P2W like high octane fuel.
If u are smart, u will suport games that dont try to get as much money from u but insted focuse on giving u a pleasure of racing against AI and ppl with as much content as u like , with mods, oficial content etc....so for me there is just GSC 2013 and Aseto Corsa that are on that level of racing, i Racing too but thats for profesional drivers not for a casual gamer..Race room expirience is a money generating machine not a racing simuator , just like World of Tanks is, Star Citisen and all other so called free games . Thank u simbin for not existing any more and making room for real racing gamers over at Asetto corsa and GSC. over and out

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game enough. Sure it has it's foibles, but it is a game still in development and the pros far outweigh the cons.

+ Stunning sounds, everything from backfires to suspension tweaks, from transmission flex to wind buffeting.
+ Great graphics. Only DX9 sure, but wonderful lighting and colour.
+ Good physics. A little more forgiving than perhaps it should be, but they do use race driver feedback, and it makes it more accessible.
+ Awesome content. Unless you like open-wheelers, then the content is stunning, from DTM to Group 5, from WTCC to GT Masters.
+ You can try out any car before buying it, which is an awesome feature.

- The pay model has its benefits and it's disadvantages. Firstly, you only have to buy what you want, which means you can in theory pay less than a normal 'all-up front' game, in which I often find I don't use all the content anyway. The disadvantage is that it is on the expensive side for sure, though much cheaper than iRacing and there is no monthly subscription. You also only need one car from any group of cars to be able to compete with the others, like iRacing.
- The servers are still not stable, but is something they are working on, and is improving at a decent rate.
- Would be better if the circuits were laser-scanned, though the upcoming Nordschleife will be.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm conflicted over RRE - overall I've had a lot of fun so I give it's a 'recommended' but it's a mixed bag.

Good points
Most of the cars are beautifully modelled, looking and (importantly) sounding great.
Handling is mostly top-notch
Tracks are well modelled (tho Bathurst lacks the bumps it has in reality and Brands is Indy only)

Bad Points
The AI isn't the best - it's not keen to overtake, seems to have MUCH better brakes/grip and hitting/being hit by an AI car tends to result in it carrying-on and you being thrown into the scenery.
The pricing model means the odds are your mates won't have the cars/tracks you do which limits online fun a bit

I don't really mind the 'free game - pay for cars and tracks' model overall - it encourages them to keep developing the game by keeping the money coming in.

Tips:
Cars are cheaper on their own rather that in packs UNLESS you want all the LIVERIES (which make-up most of the cost)
Just because you don't own a car/livery doesn't mean the AI/other players can't use it in races (you won't be racing all-the-same cars even if you only own 1 car/livery in a class)
Adaptive AI doesn't really work (for me at least) - just dial-in your level and you'll have more fun
Test-drive any car you like from the Store (one track only but you'll get the idea)
Steam Sales offer cheap DLC packs!!

reviewText:
This is a great sim with lots of potential but will not get a lot of followers in its present state due to it having no multiplayer function.  Although it's classed as a free to play game it really isn't.  You get a couple of cars and the odd track for free but for anything else you're going to have to dig deep.  You are expected to purchase VP points for real cash and then exchange your VP points to purchase cars and tracks.  This can empty your pockets to the tune of hundreds of £.

On top of this they have other 'purchase to play' addons called 'Experiences'.  At present there is the 'DTM Experience' which bolts on to the RRE  menus but runs a full DTM 2013 season against AI.....again, with no Multiplayer.  This comes at the cost of a full game and is basically what seasoned sim racer would call a mod of RRE.  The next Experience" to come along will be the British or World Touring Car Championship in which you will be expected to shell out another 20-30 £ or Euros for.

While this is all going on you cannot use the tracks from DTM experience is the standard game of RRE.  No no no
date:
you have to buy the tracks again even though they already exist in the DTM Experience.

Even though this is a fairly decent sim it looks like Simbin will contnue to milk you for every penny they can and I for one will turn to better (And much cheaper) simulators like Assetto Corsa and rFactor 2 as they have an active modding community which provide free content as well as being able to share tracks can be between mods etc.

A great game spoilt by a rabid thirst for your money."

reviewText:
Know what you're getting into.

It's obvious a lot of effort went into this game; the realism is fantastic. However, be warned that with a high level of realism in the physics and handling comes a higher difficulty, or at least a much steeper learning curve. The game is probably much better when played on a wheel, but with a standard controller you're probably gonna have a frustrating time. I know I did.

If you live and breathe racing sims and don't mind taking the time to learn how to control the monstrously powerful cars in this game, go for it. If you're looking for a relaxing blast through the tracks with a more arcade-y feel, this definitely isn't the game for you.

Track and car selection is limited without paying, and it would be nice if all of the free cars were grouped in one list so you didn't have to search around, but pay-to-play stuff like this comes with the territory with free games.

tl;dr: This game treats racing as SRS BUSINESS, be prepared.

reviewText:
Where to start?

I'm a huge DTM fan, and this game was the only one on the market that actually let me have the experience to drive with Muller, Felix da Costa, Green and all the others.

But it does more than that. It's an actual simulator, which makes everything WAY more interesting.

The tracks are spot on, so are the cars.
This is THE racing game I always wanted, and now here it is.

Graphics are great, gameplay damn close to the real thing, and nothing else to add.

10/10 would 49.900 Norisring again with the DTM merc.

reviewText:
Admittingly, I disliked the idea of having to Pay-To-Play each series, but I have grown accustomed to it.

Basically, they have a base game (Free of charge) which they can constantly update over a period of years. On top of that, the people only purchase what they want. For example, don't like WTCC? Don't buy it. Really like Norising but not DTM? Just get the track. I feel as though this is a good step forward for Sim Racing.

However, Online Sim Racing Leagues will struggle with the lack of customizable skins for the cars. They might end up editing their game to help these Leagues (as I said, they will only be updating the base game) able to use the game.

reviewText:
I am really enjoying this alot.
Had this on steam years ago but didn't actually play much and never bought any content that seems at the time rather highly priced.
Sometime or another an update wrecked my FFB and I uninstalled and forgot about it.

Now about 2 years later I try it again.
It really is very nice and very immersive.
Buying 1 pack from stream and then later much cheaper now when I buy ingame store. I guess a big part of that is content I now already own from buying that first pack, so in the end prices are really not too bad.

I am enjoying driving at Nordschleife with this sim much more than I ever did with either AC or Pcars.
The combination of great sound, graphics, forcefeedback and overall feel really puts you in the driving mood.

reviewText:
Racer check this out. The best racing sim at the moment!

Such an immersion gives you none! Sound, gfx and speeeed :D This is really an experience!

For some months i have turned my back and was in iRacing and Loeb Rally. Now after the last patch - 31/3/2016 - my racer heart is pumping stronger :D Nordschleife is out!

The new Nordschleife is a beauty and huuugggeee fun to race online with enough racers! - (btw I prefer online racing).

R3E gives you an amount of content, AI-racing is becoming better and better and you have the mp-part - which lacks of some features so far. With the AI you can race after the patch on SPA and Nordschleife with up to 100 racer grid. Starting from the back and fighting to the leader is fun sometimes for me.  Lets hope for a bright online future ;D The multiplayer needs more online racer and more polish by the devs.

The controls are superb for me: In use is here a G27 with a Th8RS shifter and from time to time i like to race in the right sofa-mood with my xbox-controller in Sound"-view ;D

Try the free part and there is the possibility to try all cars on one track. Check it out! Absolute worth it!

For more infos visit the devs-forum:

https://forum.sector3studios.com/index.php?find-new/1901361/posts

Have fun!

Harryo

PS: Leave the FOV on 1.0 - real FOV cockpit view - and change the seat-position to your liking. You will have the best feeling so far your screen is big enough ;D

PPS: Just now the devs have released the Audi R18 :D i have to go! Cya on the track and drive with respect online!"

reviewText:
With each and every update this game just keeps getting better and better , RRE competes on every level with any AAA title released to date , this game in my opinion is fast becoming a work of art , graphically and technically RRE has exceeded all my expectations and cannot be overlooked by any sim racer.

The driving experience is very realistic and suited to players of all levels. The UI is particularly nice and offers everything you could possibly think you want, options are really well laid out in a manner which suits the whole presentation package perfectly,  a lot of work and thought has went into this title and anyone who loves attention to detail will no doubt agree, this is one of the very best sim racers available on PC , ( if not the best ).

RRE also has some of the best force feed back and FFB options I have experienced in any racing title.

Simply Awesome 10/10 a must have sim.

reviewText:
Absolutely f***** fantastic!!!!

If you want to race real racing cars and not mess about thrashing road cars then this is for you!
As for all the negative feedback, yes! it is getting expensive as ive spent around £30 quid on this sim so far, however! What the negative feedback fails to mention is this, YOU CAN TEST DRIVE ANY CAR FOR FREE!!!
You do only get a few tracks to start with, but now you seem to get a whole load more cars for free, trust me its worth spending some time with this sim just for the sound and the free test driving..... hop in the Ford Capri Race Car, I spent and hour test driving it simply for the insane noise it makes, id short shift most of the time and then treat myself to the odd high rev just to hear the engine, it actually gave me goose bumps!

So then the physics.......... all I need to say here is that actual real racing drivers use this as training, TIMO GLOCK is one name that springs to mind, his profile in game reveals over 4 days of gameplay haha. Yes its a hard game to master and I'm a long way off, if I'm lucky I can get in the top 30% on a leaderboard and ive been playing these games/sims for over 15 years.

Graphics are not the greatest but you get the feeling more of the processing power is being used on the physics engine than on processing eye candy. Real sense of rubber and tarmac like you used to get with RACE07.

And the sound..... once again its worth throwing a few quid at this title just for the sound. Its sexy.

reviewText:
There are some truly god aful reviews here. Not liking the game because you have to buy content is not a legitimate reason to leave a negative review.    You have to buy everything these days and why is that different here?   It's cost is comparative to any other title  when yuo add a few content packs into play.  Yes if you add them all you will spend more money then an entire game, you also end up with Laser Scanned tracks, some of the best driving physics a simulation has

Graphically the game is a little behind but it IMO actually does a great job at looking the most realistic and providing most realistic feel when racing.    RF2 does an ok job here but being DX9 only is a hold back.  AC is gorgeous but not real,  Project Cars looks like a video game.  PC looks the best, but also has the worst driving model and is not realistic in look at all.

If you enjoyed Race 07, GTR2, and GTR Evolution you will like RRE.  To me this is the spiritual success of these  titles and I will continue to support both Simbing/Sector3 and ISI and their Gmotor efforts.   Ian and Project Cars well lets just say I have PCars but ill never buy it.

reviewText:
Great game.

I've played Forza, GT...love GT6, but damn! Raceroom is fun. I bought the WTCC addon (but I love WTCC) and it's a blast to drive. The FWD physics is awesome...awesome = realistic durining corning and hard braking. Then I bought the GT3 addon (everything was bought during Xmas sales) and it was a blast, I still need traction control but perfection comes with time (plus i'm using the xbox controller). Buying  some of the tracks is a bit lame, to be honest but that's how this developer pays their employees.

I use a 8 core AMD , 32 gbs o' ram with 2 gtx 760's...more than enough for this game. It runs AMAZING.

If you love racing give this a shot and get the some of the addons while their still on xmas discount.

reviewText:
Play Simracing since GTR2, so i have a good overview about SImgames. Now we have some good Simracing games like Assetto Corsa and Iracing. The difference between this two games and RRRE is that the Forcefeedack are much more real then the other two games. Enginesound from all cars are more real and you think youre inside your dreamcar.

short pro and contra list:

+Engine Sound
+ForceFeedback
+collision detection (much much better then Assetto Corsa)
+Racing Tracks (not all laserscanned but real similar to the real tracks)
+Racecars (DTM13/14,WTCC13,GTR1/2/3/X,GTMasters,Daytona,Procars and much more)
+OnTrack Settings like (control, HUD,Sound, etc.)I miss that in Assetto Corsa
+dedicated server still in development (comming soon)
+RealRace Drivers use this game to train (Sometimes you see one of your Racestar ingame)
+everycar have a own setup what you can edit how you want - steering options for everycar
+MP: Friends shown as a star in the Serverlist

-/+Microtransactions (You can buy a complete Pack like GTMasters or DTM 13/14.
-/+Multiplayer in Alpha Stage (some stuff is missed)
-just few onlineplayers
-Multiplayer: Training/Qualitime: Players join during sessions, a join lag destroy your Laptime
-Setupguide is missing (example. Assetto Corsa explain ingame what every option mean)
-MP: Loadtime while joining a server take a long time (maybe 2-3 minutes)


Most stuff is in development and the devs are working hard.

I think that this game is one of the top sims actually,

reviewText:
I'm going with a 'yes' to 'do you recommend this game ?', but that 'yes' needs to be qualified.  If you want an easy arcade style game, as a lot of the other reviews suggest to me, then move on, this isn't a game, it's a serious simulation.  Like most serious simulations, you can't expect to get everything in one download.  You buy the base and then you add the elements that interest you, just like people did with scalextric or electric train sets back in the good old days :)  The advantage of this offering is that the first part is free.  It doesn't include a lot, but if you have some patience, there is enough to get a feel for what is on offer and decide if you want more.

I have tried both Assetto Corsa and RaceRoom Experience this past week.  My first impression was that Assetto Corsa was better.  It cetainly has the better interface and the option to set up the cars to some degree is attractive.  RR3 has some problems with it's server and the current Nvidia drivers, but, while frustrating, these are not major issues, assuming these will be fixed in the near futures.  Both simulations promise multiplayer options, although it looks like the RR3 option will be limited to the DM Experience DLC for now.  For me the availability of the DM Experience tips the odds in favour of RR3 for the moment, but I'm happy to follow both for now and see what the future brings.

One final word regarding control options.  I haven't tried either simulation with a mouse/keyboard option and I don't think this would be much fun.  A PC xbox 360 controller is what I am using at the moment and I find it adequate for the for the 'amateur', as opposed to 'novice' level of skill.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic racing sim.  It is not an arcade game, it is not Gran Turismo or Need for Speed.  To get the most out of this game will require a wheel and pedal set.  It is free but only comes with basic content, the rest is paid but it is enough to try it out -  more content is very reasonable and there are no microtransactions or subscription.

Players include professional race car drivers.  To be the fastest person he will take a lot of doing.  Not really for people who don't love driving race cars and don't mind being beaten a lot.  There are no street cars in this game.  There are ongoing competions and many many hotlap leaderboards.

I have been sim racing for a long time and at the moment this and Game Stock Car are all I want to play.

If you play this for 6 minutes with a keyboard and then hate it because you are struggling instead of winning everything in sight as on an EA game leaving a bad review is unfair.  Note that these people are in the multiplayer on the free content and if you are worried the other multiplayer is a lot cleaner although there is no safety rating system as yet.

If you like driving realistic race cars get this game.

reviewText:
Pozitívumok:
-nagyon szép grafika, magas FPS (közepes gépigénye van a játéknak)
-sokféle autó, pálya részletesen lemodellezve
-online versenyzői felület, ami jól használható (LFS-del ellentétben)
-a kocsikat és pályákat DLC formájában lehet megvenni, így mivel nekem nem volt szükségem sok autóra, olcsóbb mint a Project CARS
-demóban ki lehet próbálni többféle autót és pályát is, tesztelni lehet azokat az autókat, amiket venni szeretnél
-bajnokságok
-elképesztő Force Feedback (DFGT) és hang

Negatívumok:
-elég drágák a DLC-k
-mindig csak a tavalyi autók vannak lemodellezve
-nem használhatók jól a szerverek
-nagyon zavaró, mikor az AI csapattársak ütköznek, mert nem megyek elég gyorsan

Összességében nekem tetszett a játék, mindenképpen próbáld ki a demót!

reviewText:
I noticed that most people who did a negative review of this game played less than 1 hour ......
If you ever like'd Race 07 , gtr , gtr2 etc etc , you like this game also .
I first bought me a car to get out of the open servers  and found a bunch of people who liked racing!!
There are always some servers with atleast 7 / 10 people around..
Tracks are nice and the physics & force feedback are great , not to difficult to drive fast but to get that last second of you'r time you have to practise..
Default setups are not far off pace and enough to have a decent race with and be not the one at the back of the field.

After a while i bought me the packs i wanted and a few single cars to participate in online races in almost every class there is .
So if you only like to drive online against other players the costs are not much more or equal as any other racing game.
btw  , single races with the purchased cars are possiblle (even championships) and you get the whole field of cars to that class (not driveable) for free so you don't race 25 the same cars that you have ( buy 1 gt3 and the whole gt3 pack race's with you) :)  Great !
So next time you buy a beer in a bar ,  you have to think that that beer also could have been a nice GT3 in this game ...

Ohw yeah...  BUY A WHEEL !!!  and try again after your negative revieuw .... this is a SIM..

reviewText:
Raceroom is a great racing simulator. It has good physics and graphics, and AMAZING sounds. Simbin has done a great job capturing the feel. Now, the downside I'm goign to point out is that this is not entirely free to play. It is essentially a base game with a couple cars and tracks. Extra tracks and cars must be bought. Raceroom is constantly being updated with new content, if you want to buy stuff wait until it goes on sale. Everything eventually will go on sale for at least %50 off. If you ever need any input the raceroom discussion board is a great place as well.

==In Short==: Awesome Racing Sim, but Not Truly FTP.

reviewText:
First off let me say, Im a HUGE fan of project cars... That being said..I just got this game today and for this being early access and only having 5 cars and 3  tracks (with about 4-6 variations on each track) to start off freely... THIS GAME IS AMAZING. The physics and force feedback on my G27 are just spot on.

1. Graphics - 8/10 - There are prettier games out there.. but lets face it.. its early access and they still look great.
2. Sound - 10/10.. Ive never heard such satisfying superchargers, turbos and crunching suspensions in a game to this day.
3. Physics - 10/10 - Somehow they really make you feel every little bump, dip and lateral movement better than any racing game i've played to date.
4. Car Setup - 7/10 - This is the only part that feels lacking, Being early acess we can only hope it improves.
5. Multiplayer -10/10 Ive played it all morning and loved every minute of it. There are of course all the drivers who do not have respect for others, im sure its just the flood of free to play" players trying the game out. Its very competetive in real sim mode with no racing lines available making you pay close attention to your speed and braking points. Have not tried novice and ameture mode so can offer no comment if racing line is available at all."

reviewText: I think this game is one to watch. It really is a very high quality racing simulator especially considering it is free. A little too far down the realism spectrum for my liking though. The main problem is that there is no sense of accomplishment or incentive to keep playing. In most racing games you win races to unlock new tracks and cars which keeps you wanting to play on. But here you unlock new stuff by buying it. Also the races them self are just against the clock. There is very little sense of accomplishment from just moving a few places up the leader boards. So as I say I think this is one to keep an eye on as more content become available.

reviewText:
*** German translation in comments section / Deutsche Übersetzung als Kommentar ***

First of all, my review is based on playing R3E with a wheel (Fanatec GT3RS v2 + Clubsport Pedals v1) and in GetReal"-mode only. So the FFB + physics part may not match the driving experience of gamepad users. The driving at other difficulty levels (Novice or Amateur) may also differ.

Graphics:
The overall graphics are quite nice
date: but sometimes the whole scenery looks a little bit "cartoony". Maybe it lacks better shaders to give the graphics a more real touch. Nevertheless i like the graphics
recommended:
but improvements are always welcome.
The available tracks are well-made. As a sidenote .... i like the swaying trees. These small details adds to immersion.
Big immersion breaker: The big colored distance markers!
I hope Simbin brings us an option soon to replace these arcade-style signs with realistic corner/brake/distance markers.

Sound:
Actually R3E has the best sound of all available Simracing titles (incl. the Simulations in beta-
hoursPlayed: alpha-
voteText:
pre-alpha-status). But iRacing and pCARS are on the way to close the gap (or are on par with some cars). It seems that more and more developer have recognized now the important role of realistic sounds to improve the immersion.
Just a small point of criticism: In external TV-cam the engine should be a little bit louder and lasts longer on departure.

Force Feedback:
IMHO the FFB is one of the things which needs to improve in R3E. The whole system with different "FFB effects level" and its canned effects is kinda old school. It seems that there's too much "ancient" ISI-motor stuff in use. (BTW ... Reiza Studios demonstrate greatly with Game Stock Car 2013 what is still possible with the aged physics engine)
The FFB effects should come right from the physics (suspension + tires). Just like RealFeel-FFB or/and LeoFFB plugins for rFactor. All these canned effects e.g. for rumblestrips aren't necessary
helpfulPercent: if the FFB would come direct from the physics. Furthermore some of these canned effects settings makes it more difficult to get the FFB feel right.\nAlso the default controller files aren't that good out-of-the-box. For most players it is necessary to play with all the FFB parameters to find some settings
votesHelpful: whereby you feel comfortable with. And there are a lot of these FFB parameters
votesTotal:
which actually aren't accessable via the GUI. It might be not an easy "Start & Race" and this could discourage R3E newcomers.

Physics:
Goes a little bit hand in hand with the FFB. If the FFB is badly configured you can't get the right feel for the car/physics. But if you find some good settings for your wheel
votesFunny: then the physics come to live too.\nA few times the word "simcade" was mentioned within the community. I'm not agree with that. Many of us are used to the older sims (e.g. GTR2
commentsCount: rFactor1
column16: etc.) and its kind of "low grip feeling"
column17: which makes you believe that race cars are very difficult to drive. But that's not the case. Race cars are well balanced and build to give you tons of grip
column18:
and not to kill the driver in every corner. Only driving on the limit makes it difficult and will separate the winners from the losers. ;) I think that R3E has implemented this grippy track feeling very well. That's not a reason to call R3E not a sim (or "simcade").

Multiplayer:
Not yet available. Only leaderboard challenges where you can race against ghost cars (recorded by other players) are possible at the moment.
Furthermore there are actually almost no official informations about the planned multiplayer features for R3E.

F2P
column19: Content & Pricing:\nFree2Play but actually not much free content. Even if there are almost constantly competitions and try-before-you-buy events
column20: but a little more free stuff would be good.\nReferring to the not-free content
column21: i think the prices for cars and tracks are quite fair. You can drive a car for years and have much fun on a well-made track
column22: and now compare it with the small fee you must pay for it. Otherwise .... if you want all the tracks and cars
column23: it might become very very expensive. I would like to see some bundled packs as special offer from Simbin.\nWhat i didn't like is the Livery-part. I have always liked to paint my own car skins. Now i have to pay for a livery and the available real liveries do cost too much. And if you buy a car
column24: i would appreciate that 2-3 liveries (different ones and not only a changed numberplate) are included at least
column25: just to have a basic choice. Look at the leaderboards ........ almost every driver is driving the provided standard livery. And now imagine some multiplayer races later on
column26: where almost everyone is driving the same car skin."

reviewText: First of all I'm a big racing sim nut, I dont go for those other titles like need for speed, get a console if you like those games. Over all I like this game, its very easy to pick up, very good graphics and physics, and enjoyable, I only have the DTM add on so far and am enjoying it greatly, I've tried playing with both gamepad and steering wheel and the enjoyment is there for both. what I dont like is the amount of DLC's you end up paying for, I really wish the games industry would migrate away from this, unfortunately this game is by far the worst I have in my steam account for this, and the main reason I havent bought more packs. overall yes its a good game, the multiplayer states its still in alpha, so there are better games out there, personally iracing does what this lacks very well. as for Ai, I hate to say it but Project cars probably has the best AI I have come across in a modern racing game. For those who havent got this game yet, should you get it? yes, but choose a DLC pack that you will like and stick with, dont go crazy buying all the packs.

reviewText:
For being a free game, I'd say it's more than decent, but how a car handles feels kind of unrealistic sadly, and there's almost no car fitted for hillclimb really and the amount of cars you can choose betwen right now, both free cars and those you'll have to pay for isn't exactly a big and long list, yet, I guess. Either way, I'd still give this game so far a 6.5 out of 10.



[Edit] I won't change my mind about this game being pretty good for being free, however, it sucks that most cars cost real money, and what sucks most is that the loading screen for each race is so extremely long, it seriously take about 2-5 minutes each time you want to do a race, whenever it's for testing out a car, practice or even real race. From a 6.5 out of 10, it takes a spring down to 4.8 out of 10 just because of the long time on loading screen.

What also sucks enormously is sometimes when you slide, even the slightst, it's almost impossible to recover from that almost regardless of what car you drive, it's very arcade-ish that part and it takes away a lot of the great racing feeling, because it feels like you're driving on a crappy Need For Speed game...

reviewText:
First of all, this game is extremely hard with a keyboard. Actually i would not recommend to play it without any proper controller. There are 3 difficulties:
-Get Real: Its not possible to go around a track without spinning
-Amateur: Its kind of okey with keyboard, but the traction control will ruin a lot of your laps
-Novice: I havent tried it, cause it contains a braking assistant.

The sad thing was, that if the car started to slide, there was basically no chance of properly holding it. Most of the times opposite lock and throttle lift felt like they have no effect at all. In amateur difficulty all cars I tried had horrible understeer ( barely any tiresqueel, though ).

The menu system is not userfriendly. If you are used to normal, traditional GUI, then you will have a hard time finding things. After 5 hours of play its still strange, not comfortable to use.

On the bright side: The game looks amazing. The challanges can make the game addictive ( so you can find entertainment/motivation to play for  years ). The cars noises and twitches make the atmosphere amazing. You can really feel like you are in the car. In Get Real difficulty there are a lot of settings you can change on the car, so simulator fans can be happy.

Summary: I recommend this game for a try, maybe you will love it. Steering wheel is very much needed.
