reviewText:
***EDIT-2015***
If you had told me at the time I first wrote this review that things were just about to turn around and that this would become one of my favorite games of 2015 (and hopefully later) I would have had you committed.

But that's exctly what happened. Big shake ups went on at Simbin and the company is now called Sector 3". But more than that
date: whoever it was that made the majority of the wrong decisions about this game must either be gone or he/she has seen the light.\n\nI have changed my review to reflect the great advances this game made. I will also write a more comprehensive review at some point in the future
recommended:
but for now suffice to say that this game should be in every race enthusiast library.

-------------------OLD REVIEW BELOW-------------------------------



It pains me not to reccomend this game. I own every single Simbin game ever published and I still race in a GTR2 league with weekly races where we manage to have 30 to 40 rivers per 1h or 1:30 hour race. Every week
hoursPlayed: year around.\n\nNaturally
voteText: GTR2 is showing its age
helpfulPercent: but it is still the only racing simulator with day/night transitions
votesHelpful: full pit experience
votesTotal:
large fields and all the other features that make a simulator awesome.

We waited for GTR3 for a long time and we were very excited by Simbin early previews of their new sound engine. It was truly something to behold.
Then GTR3 fizzled and Raceroom Racing Experience came out as a "free to play" game. Initially I was quite impressed. The sound was awesome and far superior to anything else out there. The graphics

but passable.

Even as a free to play game it had promise and initially we belived it would become something at least playable if not a substiotute for GTR2.

reviewText: First of all I'm a big racing sim nut, I dont go for those other titles like need for speed, get a console if you like those games. Over all I like this game, its very easy to pick up, very good graphics and physics, and enjoyable, I only have the DTM add on so far and am enjoying it greatly, I've tried playing with both gamepad and steering wheel and the enjoyment is there for both. what I dont like is the amount of DLC's you end up paying for, I really wish the games industry would migrate away from this, unfortunately this game is by far the worst I have in my steam account for this, and the main reason I havent bought more packs. overall yes its a good game, the multiplayer states its still in alpha, so there are better games out there, personally iracing does what this lacks very well. as for Ai, I hate to say it but Project cars probably has the best AI I have come across in a modern racing game. For those who havent got this game yet, should you get it? yes, but choose a DLC pack that you will like and stick with, dont go crazy buying all the packs.

reviewText:
This is pure simulator with almost none of virtual help, it's all up to you and your driving style, I love that in simulators when they just put you in action and leave you to learn about the game through the gameplay. When I started playing I thought this game is all about paying for extra stuff. Yea, it is expensive as hell, but its a good game. Sure, only 1 fictional track for use is terrible. The sound is awesome and so are the physics.

First feel: 6/10

Gameplay: 9/10

Controller support: 9/10

Physics 9/10 - Driving: 10/10
Crashing physics: 10/10
Crash damage: 3/10

Sound: 11/10

Price: 3/10

Overall game experience: 9/10 - Very fun but very expensive and a lot of locked stuff ruins the fun gameplay. Especially if you have to pay for every car and track.
Edit: Most of the competitions lend you everything neccessery for racing, so you can explore new cars and tracks. That feature is very good.

reviewText: I think this game is one to watch. It really is a very high quality racing simulator especially considering it is free. A little too far down the realism spectrum for my liking though. The main problem is that there is no sense of accomplishment or incentive to keep playing. In most racing games you win races to unlock new tracks and cars which keeps you wanting to play on. But here you unlock new stuff by buying it. Also the races them self are just against the clock. There is very little sense of accomplishment from just moving a few places up the leader boards. So as I say I think this is one to keep an eye on as more content become available.

reviewText:
*** German translation in comments section / Deutsche Übersetzung als Kommentar ***

First of all, my review is based on playing R3E with a wheel (Fanatec GT3RS v2 + Clubsport Pedals v1) and in GetReal"-mode only. So the FFB + physics part may not match the driving experience of gamepad users. The driving at other difficulty levels (Novice or Amateur) may also differ.

Graphics:
The overall graphics are quite nice
date: but sometimes the whole scenery looks a little bit "cartoony". Maybe it lacks better shaders to give the graphics a more real touch. Nevertheless i like the graphics
recommended:
but improvements are always welcome.
The available tracks are well-made. As a sidenote .... i like the swaying trees. These small details adds to immersion.
Big immersion breaker: The big colored distance markers!
I hope Simbin brings us an option soon to replace these arcade-style signs with realistic corner/brake/distance markers.

Sound:
Actually R3E has the best sound of all available Simracing titles (incl. the Simulations in beta-
hoursPlayed: alpha-
voteText:
pre-alpha-status). But iRacing and pCARS are on the way to close the gap (or are on par with some cars). It seems that more and more developer have recognized now the important role of realistic sounds to improve the immersion.
Just a small point of criticism: In external TV-cam the engine should be a little bit louder and lasts longer on departure.

Force Feedback:
IMHO the FFB is one of the things which needs to improve in R3E. The whole system with different "FFB effects level" and its canned effects is kinda old school. It seems that there's too much "ancient" ISI-motor stuff in use. (BTW ... Reiza Studios demonstrate greatly with Game Stock Car 2013 what is still possible with the aged physics engine)
The FFB effects should come right from the physics (suspension + tires). Just like RealFeel-FFB or/and LeoFFB plugins for rFactor. All these canned effects e.g. for rumblestrips aren't necessary
helpfulPercent: if the FFB would come direct from the physics. Furthermore some of these canned effects settings makes it more difficult to get the FFB feel right.\nAlso the default controller files aren't that good out-of-the-box. For most players it is necessary to play with all the FFB parameters to find some settings
votesHelpful: whereby you feel comfortable with. And there are a lot of these FFB parameters
votesTotal:
which actually aren't accessable via the GUI. It might be not an easy "Start & Race" and this could discourage R3E newcomers.

Physics:
Goes a little bit hand in hand with the FFB. If the FFB is badly configured you can't get the right feel for the car/physics. But if you find some good settings for your wheel
votesFunny: then the physics come to live too.\nA few times the word "simcade" was mentioned within the community. I'm not agree with that. Many of us are used to the older sims (e.g. GTR2
commentsCount: rFactor1
column16: etc.) and its kind of "low grip feeling"
column17: which makes you believe that race cars are very difficult to drive. But that's not the case. Race cars are well balanced and build to give you tons of grip
column18:
and not to kill the driver in every corner. Only driving on the limit makes it difficult and will separate the winners from the losers. ;) I think that R3E has implemented this grippy track feeling very well. That's not a reason to call R3E not a sim (or "simcade").

Multiplayer:
Not yet available. Only leaderboard challenges where you can race against ghost cars (recorded by other players) are possible at the moment.
Furthermore there are actually almost no official informations about the planned multiplayer features for R3E.

F2P
column19: Content & Pricing:\nFree2Play but actually not much free content. Even if there are almost constantly competitions and try-before-you-buy events
column20: but a little more free stuff would be good.\nReferring to the not-free content
column21: i think the prices for cars and tracks are quite fair. You can drive a car for years and have much fun on a well-made track
column22: and now compare it with the small fee you must pay for it. Otherwise .... if you want all the tracks and cars
column23: it might become very very expensive. I would like to see some bundled packs as special offer from Simbin.\nWhat i didn't like is the Livery-part. I have always liked to paint my own car skins. Now i have to pay for a livery and the available real liveries do cost too much. And if you buy a car
column24: i would appreciate that 2-3 liveries (different ones and not only a changed numberplate) are included at least
column25: just to have a basic choice. Look at the leaderboards ........ almost every driver is driving the provided standard livery. And now imagine some multiplayer races later on
column26: where almost everyone is driving the same car skin."

reviewText:
I've reconsidered my previous, extremely negative review.

The last update for this sim has helped things quite dramatically.

After playing for a couple of hours I experienced no crashes to desktop at all and the steering feels considerably better, almost perfect now on my Fanatec CSR Elite wheel.



Swapping from my single 2560 x 1440 monitor my old tripple screen 5760 x 1200 NVida Surround setup helps make the sim more addictive.

I've always liked the quality of the SimBin tracks as they're full of detail which further adds to the sense of immersion.

Despite the relatively high cost if you puchase all the tracks and get a good collection of cars, I think you'd find that this will give you hundreds of hours of entertainment.

reviewText: I am not a fan of Free2Play" games. However the prices for vehicles and tracks are reasonable and very often additionally discounted. I bought a bunch today at 50% off. The tracks were around $2.50 and cars were $1.00 to $1.50. There is no subscription fee like in iRacing and the content is a lot less expensive but still high quality. If you are looking for a game that you don't have to spend a lot of money on this is an excellent choice. I'm really big into sim racing and this game does a good job in the realism department for the most part. It's worth trying out the free cars and tracks and buying a few if you want to expand your gameplay."

reviewText:
Hey everyone,

RRRE is worth your time.

RRRE is a absolute hidden treasure of a racing sim buried under a unattractive business model and hidden behind terrible loading menus. (i believe soon to be fixed)
Dig beyond, and you will be rewarded, handling, dynamics, visuals, sound. It has it all. Its also beautifully optimized and can run well (and still look great) on older rigs, but when you have the horsepower crank it up for amazing visuals.
This game has continually gotten better and better as the SIMBIN team from the great Race07 continue to work and improve this absolute driving masterpiece.

Do yourself a favour pic up Hockenheim in sunset with some gt3's and just sit back and enjoy.

dig.

reviewText: As a simracing beginner I have to say that I like this title. The feeling of the car is very good and the sound is just awesome. I can not describe how good and realistic it is. The apex hunt feature has helped me as a beginner to reduce my lap times and learn the tracks and breaking points. Ok there are some negative points aswell, such as missing night/day features, weather and multiplayer. Another negative point is that if you want all of the content such as tracks, cars and liveries, you better start saving up some money because it is very expensive. The overall image is good I think but not perfect. It is a developing product so it is improved with every update and the fact that it is more or less free to play ( you can drive 2 cars on one track and participate in challenges) should encourage everyone to at least try it out. I would highly suggest it for those who are simracing beginners or for those who want to see if they like simracing or not.

reviewText:
This is pure simulator with almost none of virtual help, it's all up to you and your driving style, I love that in simulators when they just put you in action and leave you to learn about the game through the gameplay. When I started playing I thought this game is all about paying for extra stuff. Yea, it is expensive as hell, but its a good game. Sure, only 1 fictional track for use is terrible. The sound is awesome and so are the physics.

First feel: 6/10

Gameplay: 9/10

Controller support: 9/10

Physics 9/10 - Driving: 10/10
Crashing physics: 10/10
Crash damage: 3/10

Sound: 11/10

Price: 3/10

Overall game experience: 9/10 - Very fun but very expensive and a lot of locked stuff ruins the fun gameplay. Especially if you have to pay for every car and track.
Edit: Most of the competitions lend you everything neccessery for racing, so you can explore new cars and tracks. That feature is very good.

reviewText: I downloaded this game at the beginning of the weekend, and I'm glad I did! Awesome free content. Although there's only a few cars to race with, you can try any of the cars in the game for free. There's only a few tracks for free, plenty more if you want to pay.  So far, using the free cars  and the free tracks, I'm definitely hooked! The sound effects are great, the cars sound like the real deal. Far better than most racing games, and in some ways, better than any racing game I've ever played. Yeah, it's that good! The physics are excellent, and you are given 3 choices for general set-up, abs,tcs,etc. I've found a happy medium with the middle choice, it lets me learn the cars and tracks easier. The tracks are beautiful, and have lots of elevation change, rumble strips, run-offs, etc. Again, I've personally only played on three of the tracks. I really like how you can set-up your race with practice and qualifying. This is something that seems lost on console racing games. My only real gripe thus far is the Ai. I've been racing with the adaptive Ai, which for one race was ridiculously easy, then the next race very hard. And going with that was the aggression of the Ai, when I braked a little earlier for a turn and got rear ended and booted from the track. Really? Sometimes damage seems to happen, other times, you can drive into a wall with no consequences. Glitch? But, gripes aside, this is a really well made game, and for free? Amazing! I will most likely end up buying more content when I get bored with the free stuff. I still can't get over the sounds!...

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying this is an incredible game. There's lots of content and the game is growing bigger step by step. I'm going to dive into some subjects a lot of negative reviews talk about and try and explain my viewpoint on them.

Multiplayer

The multiplayer is currently still developping. There are dedicated servers, and you can create your own lobbies. Multiplayer at the moment isn't very crowded, however you can have some good and fun races.

Payment model

Contrary to the Free to Play tag this game isn't free to play. A better tag would be Free Demo, but it seems this can't be helped. I'm going to compare the game with league of legends, because it's a well known free to play game. In league of legends you earn in game currency for playing, and that currency can be used to buy things. Next to the ingame currency there is a currency buyable with irl money. In RaceRoom, there is no ingame currency, just vRP, which can be bought for irl money. That's also why I don't think the Free to Play tag applies.

Now on to the paymeny model. Paying 50€ upfront for a game and unlocking all the content is very nice, but there will most likely be content you don't like or feel like playing. In RaceRoom, tracks, cars, trackpacks and carpacks can be bought seperately. Say you don't like DTM, but do like GT2, then you can just buy the GT2 cars. One thing to note is that if you want all the items, you'll be looking at a price quite a bit higher than 50€. But to put his into perspective, in league of legends you pay +- 10€ for a champion, in RaceRoom you pay +- 2.5 euro for a car.

I should also note that content can be tested for free, so you have an idea whether or not you like it.

Interface

The interface has been upadtes, is new easy to navigate and comprehend, but you still need a mouse to be able to quickly navigate menu's

Some personal insight

I do believe you need a wheel to play this game. You can you a gamepad, but then you're just not getting the complete experience.

The sounds in the game are incredible, especially with the new transmission sound update.

Graphics are great and the game runs on older hardware however there is only Dx9 support if I'm not mistaken.


As an ending I'd say, try the game out, test drive some cars, and if you like it buy some cars you enjoy driving.

reviewText: This has got to be the most underrated racing game or simulation. It may not have the best visuals among racing games right now but it still looks really good. It's FFB even though not revolutionary is something that you can tweak to suit your preferences and it's fantastic when you do.\n\nIts problem is its annoying race2play" (a play on "free 2 play") UI and it also only has a very few free cars and even fewer free tracks. I bought its GT Masters and DTM 2014 experiences and
recommended:
those are fantastic. They should make separate games for those (but give it free to us who bought them here in RRE). Or at least let us configure the game to select a default "experience" during startup.

AI in this game seems good. They don't display the "blind AI" or "AI without the I for intelligence" of other racing games and simulations.

Currently this game is still missing some polish on the HUD elements. Like the sector split times really huge and distracting when we only need to know if we're going faster or slower for the current lap. The position bar's fonts look horrible. Those things are really well done on their older games (Race series) so I hope they could really improve this area of the game. Currently those look ugly in comparison to the rest of the game that I turn them off at the expense of feedback since the game does not have a race engineer to tell you what's going on."

reviewText:
R3E was absolutely terrible not so long ago. The interface was a nightmare and the racing odd with the huge coloured markers etc. If you judge it on that, let me tell you that it's now a completely different game.

The interface now makes sense, and is one of the best you'll find out there. The game is F2P with purchases for content (but the ability to enter certain events without purchasing the content and the option to try before you buy). There are frequent sales so you don't have to spend a fortune.

Cars are very impressive with the physics being better than iRacing, Project Cars and Assetto Corsa but not quite as good as RFactor 2. Tracks, while not laser scanned, are not too far off the quality of RF2's non-laser-scanned tracks. The geometry is generally accurate, but of course you don't get the exact bumps, but laser scans quickly become out of date so this isn't as big an issue as one might expect. Sounds are the best you'll find anywhere, really expressing the clunky rattling shaking madness of a real race car.

Netcode needs a bit of work [cars behave strangely with high pings and disconnects happen], but multiplayer is in alpha I believe, so hopefully that'll improve in time. The usual issues of only 30% finishing and loads of wrecks apply in public servers but plenty of leagues exist to cater to the more serious racer. Single-player features the most enjoyable AI I've raced against.

In short, R3E is VASTLY better than it was, and now deserves a place among the elite of sim-racing.

reviewText: This game is a good start to driving sims. If you picked up your brand new 900-1080 degree FFB wheel and you got no money left over, look no further than this gem. The physics are on par with the lazer scaned iracing, and super car fun fest Asseto Corrsa. The begining cars and tracks are fun to learn, and really give you a sense of joy when shaving off 1/4 a second of a hotlap all while realizing how this is meaningless. There are 3 main modes of difficulty: Novice- Babies first racing sim, Amateur- X360 gamepad user, and Get Real- Why am I backwards and why is my front end smashed in? The only complaint is that the DLC is not only hard on the conusmer, it makes finding servers a living hell. The full experiece will cost you upwards of $100 and it is hard to justify that when other games cost around $50 and have the same content.

reviewText:
I laugh at people complaining about poor optimisation. I run this on an i7 2600k with 16GB DDR3 1600Mhz RAM and 2 780ti gpu in sli at 3440 x 1440 with 20 to 30 cars on grid and average 60 to 80 fps with graphics on max on windows 10.

The game itself is ok and can be fun, granted the handling is average but it is fun. By no means is it a sim, thats another discussion, but if you enjoy driving and have a wheel or controller (the game is controller friendly) then you will enjoy this. Only issue is the dlc but if your sensible and wait for dlc sale in the in game store, you can pickup content as you go for a reasonable price.

RRE isnt my go to driivng game, but it is good enough that I do keep coming back to it.

reviewText: This is the best sim since Grand Prix Legends. Simply the most fun you can have with your clothes on. Period. If you love race cars & racing this is as close as you can get to the real thing. They even give you a couple of tracks &  3 cars for free, Whats to complain about. Yes Multiplayer is in alpha. So if you do that then you can expect problems. But the single player game is great against the ai. Works fine & is stable on my Pc. Try it. You won't be disapointed. But as said by others. Buy your upgrades direct from the games website. Not through Steam. You can purchace from your steam wallet. It's not perfect yet there still working on it. But it is good.... Very good! Bought some tracks including one I've actually driven on & it's spot on. When you crash it doesn't even cost you anything!!!! Hell I love this game already & I only had it a few days! Works well with a joystick. So you don't have to spend a fortune on a wheel. Now I've got the thing calibrated good bye life...... :-)\nSure if your looking for arcade forget it. You will hate it. Go and waste your money on something else. Bore your brains out after 15 hours. This will take you that long to get into it. Trust me I'm only just starting. This can only get better, With more tracks coming online all the time it will be alot better. And when they sort the multiplayer........... Bought 7 tracks & 20 cars for £20 so don't believe the doom merchants. Much cheaper from the games website than on steam, This is one game I don't mind paying for DLC''s as it will keep the game in developement. Real world physics. Awesome sound that deserves some decent speakers. And after all they give you so much for free. How you can whinge about that. If it doesn't work on your system then at least it hasn't cost you anything. I have paid good money for other race games that won't even run on my Pc or have no controller support. This game is quality.

reviewText:
R3E was absolutely terrible not so long ago. The interface was a nightmare and the racing odd with the huge coloured markers etc. If you judge it on that, let me tell you that it's now a completely different game.

The interface now makes sense, and is one of the best you'll find out there. The game is F2P with purchases for content (but the ability to enter certain events without purchasing the content and the option to try before you buy). There are frequent sales so you don't have to spend a fortune.

Cars are very impressive with the physics being better than iRacing, Project Cars and Assetto Corsa but not quite as good as RFactor 2. Tracks, while not laser scanned, are not too far off the quality of RF2's non-laser-scanned tracks. The geometry is generally accurate, but of course you don't get the exact bumps, but laser scans quickly become out of date so this isn't as big an issue as one might expect. Sounds are the best you'll find anywhere, really expressing the clunky rattling shaking madness of a real race car.

Netcode needs a bit of work [cars behave strangely with high pings and disconnects happen], but multiplayer is in alpha I believe, so hopefully that'll improve in time. The usual issues of only 30% finishing and loads of wrecks apply in public servers but plenty of leagues exist to cater to the more serious racer. Single-player features the most enjoyable AI I've raced against.

In short, R3E is VASTLY better than it was, and now deserves a place among the elite of sim-racing.

reviewText:
There seems to be a lot of negative reviews on Steam about this game, especially revolving around the pricing structure, and while I agree that the price looks quite high I have to say that I think the items are so good that to me they're worth the outlay.  You get what you pay for and the quality here outshines any misgivings regarding prices.
Graphically it's stunning especially with everything turned high and running at 60fps with 22 cars on the track, for which I'm referring to DTM experience, but the hot lapping in the base game with Ai turned on gives you an insight into what the finished game will feel like and in my opinion they have got it spot on.
I can only assume that the base game is yet to be optimised because I get lower FPS on the same tracks, with only a couple of cars out than I do with the 22 cars in a full race of DTM. Same graphics settings for both but with a 10 fps drop in the base game?
Sounds are incredible, I've never been so engrossed in the sounds of any game as this one and playing with headphones on just highlights the beauty of these cars.
Gameplay is great especially on the Get Real setting, althought the Ai needs a little bit more speed as its currently too easy to catch and overtake.
I'm currently using a Razer Sabertooth gamepad and once setup it works perfectly but I can only imagine how much more fun a steering wheel would make this and it's the game which will likely push me to make that commitment.
It's that good that I've bought pretty much most of the buyable stuff, except for a couple of livery options, within just a few days of trying it.

EDIT : May 26th 2016

After having set myself up with some decent hardware to get the most out of driving games I can say that this is my favourite driving experience on the PC. I own most if not all of the PC racing sims but there's something about Raceroom that makes it very special to me, and that's the feeling you get from the overall atmosphere that this sim creates. From the sounds to graphics to driving feel, once set up correctly this is such a cool experience with AI that can keep up and give you a thrilling racing experience.

reviewText:
Positives +Free to Play
+Good graphics and sound
+Great leaderboard system, accessible online

Negatives -Limited content available for free, however you can 'try-before-you-buy' many cars/tracks.
-Expensive DLC and in-app purchases (well over $100 total) - however, you can be selective in what you purchase in order to compete online, and 'packs' are often discounted substantially. Purchase all DLC through the store - as it subtracts what you already own from the cost, and provides higher discounts than with Steam.
-No 3rd party mods as with Assetto Corsa

Verdict >Vastly improved over the last few months, I'd now consider it a worthy complementary in a Sim Racer's library to Assetto Corsa and pCARS.

reviewText:
RaceRoom is a very good game. I've really enjoyed the hours I have spent on it so far.

This is the short version of the review:
Pros
+The sounds are superb
+The graphics are nice
+The car handling is very good
+The tracklist is seems very cool
+The carlist is very good (Only racecars, mind you)
+The menus are easy to use
+The in-game interface is easy to understand
+Extremely detailed tuning
+The AI is good

Cons
-Very limited in cars and tracks if you do not pay for them
-You need a gamepad or steering wheel to enjoy the game
-Tyres seem to last unrealisticly long (Might just be me, I am not experienced in real racing)
-Damage can only be enabled on the hardest difficulty (For explanation, see below)
-The pit menu is a bit fiddly

This is the longer version of the review:
RaceRoom is a very good simulator racing game. This is how it works:
There are three difficulty settings. Novice, Amateur and GetReal.
Novice is the easiest. It has Traction Control, Anti-Lock Brakes and Auto Braking.
Amateur is the middle ground. It only has TC and ABS.
GetReal surely does what is says. It gets real. No assists enabled.
GetReal is only usable for those with a gamepad or a steering wheel. On a keyboard is utterly useless.
There is a damage model, but it can only be used in the GetReal" mode
date: which seems odd to me. In the "GetReal" mode
recommended: you can choose if you want mechanical damage
hoursPlayed: only cosmetic or none at all. The game also includes a penalty system for corner cutting. You can set it to different kinds of penalties. A slow down penalty
voteText: a drive-through penalty or a stop-and-go penalty (Be aware
helpfulPercent: you'll have to select to serve it manually. Just driving through the pits to serve a drive-through won't work).\nWhen you don't pay any money you get acces to three tracks and seven or eight (could be wrong
votesHelpful: might be less) cars. Two circuits and one hillclimb course. You can test drive any car you like as many times as you like
votesTotal: but only on a specific track. For the test drive
votesFunny: you can select the difficulty mode. You cannot test drive the tracks
commentsCount:
which I think is odd.
The game sounds fantastic and looks very good as well.
The tuning in the game is unbelievably detailed and quite frankly scarily detailed. I daren't touch it.

Overall
column16:
I think it is a great simulator which everyone interested in racing should give a try.

(This line of text contains some extra love for the people who read the review this far. I've put more time than I should have into this review)

"

reviewText:
Before i start i need to ell you that this should neither have thumbs up or down.

(Expand the page for the more positive stuff)

At first i posted a negative review because  of its STUPID FREE TO PLAY mecanic and how they charge crasy amounts of money to play more than the bad cars (that i have not tuched since i bought DTM Experience) on Raceroom Raceway and Portimao to be able to really enjoy the game. just take a track for example, a less known and popular track costs 3€ and a legendary track like SPA and Monza costs 5€. And the cars, just to buy 1 car (with all paintjobs for it) it costs 3€. To not pay as much i recomend buying one of the EXPERIENCE packs like DTM and ADAC to get some good cars and tracks.

Apart from that stupid pay system the game is good. they update the game regulary and are adding new things now and then. The physics are good but not perfict. The sound is great. The visuals are amazing. The adaptive AI should mark a milestone in racing sims and are the greatest feature. If you pay for the stuff in game you will get an amazing game.

reviewText:
The Overview This game is a very well developed racing simulator similar to that of Grand Turismo on the PlayStation. It offers a very wide selection of cars/tracks to choose from, all of which have very different attributes. The game itself is very well engineered with great graphics and it actually shocked me when I saw that this game was free (you pay for extra tracks, etc.).

Pros 1. Great Graphics
2. Great Sound
3. No Loud Main Menu Music
4. Great Map Selection
5. Very Specific Settings
6. Car Tuning
7. Turning/Acceleration Sensativity Settings
8. Free
9. Many Different Modes Of Gameplay

Cons 1. Turning Too Sensative (No Matter The Setting)
2. Takes Alot Of Practice
3. Only Get A Few Maps Free
4. Turns Take Too Much Breaking (Ridiculous Amount)

Conclusion I recommend this game for anyone looking for an amazing racing simulator game! This is on par with Grand Turismo and better yet, its free versus the $59.99 for the new Grand Turismo's. This game is very well developed and I look for updates to come out to fix any cons that I mentioned (most of which were just my opinion, not real problems).

reviewText:
Note that this really is not a free to play simulation. The free content is no good. To see what this is all about you have to spend cash to get the good packs.

Basically it is like this:

If you follow real life racing and have a 250 usd+ steering wheel setup and knowledge of and love for real life racing dynamics... and 100 usd+ to spend on content. Then this is your sim.

It is hands down the best simulation of actual RACING ever made and with the recent updates it is very close to life like racing. Now that adaptive ai is working it is also the best simulation for single player.

The fact that physics are developed in unison with the real DTM/TT drivers (whom you also see sometimes online) as well as the general engine being awesome makes this the best package right now if you have all prerequisites. If not you will not like it.

You need:

Expensive steering wheel set (without this, do not get it)
100 USD cash for different content (without this, do not get it)
Real life racing knowledge (without this, do not get it)
Following of real life racing and a love for actual track racing (without this, do not get it)


So, disregard the free to play thing. This is a hardcore platform for simulation racing, with a good single player structure as well.


If you like some more casual game" style get Project Cars
If you like hot-lapping with road cars get Assetto Corsa
If you like to devote 16 hours a day towards virtual league racing and disregard the rest of your life
date: get rFactor2\n\nIf you want a good simulation of actual racing
recommended: that is also a good single player
hoursPlayed: offline experience and need a full simulation model
voteText: get this"

reviewText:
I love cars and 3D racing games and this game gives a good explanation of racing with a variety of tracks and cars to choose from but there are four problems. First there is only one track you have to choose from as far as I can see and you have to pay for the rest of them and I use Aussie Dollars not USD, so that makes it even harder for me to buy the game currency. Second there are only two cars you start off with, the Aquila and the BMW. There both great I can tell you that but the Aquila has just poor steering and same goes with the BMW. Third I don't know how to earn the game currrency so that is a big problem for me. Last it said 2 hours to install and it took 7 hours and I had to wait a day for it to fully load.

I would recommend this game to car and racing fans but just look out for poor steering because the first track you use has a few hard turns and you have to really judge you turning because the turn, most of the time is hard to make and when your in first person view you see the steering wheel only turn a small amount not going in a full rotation like other games. You also have to wait a couple of seconds before the cars goes from N to D or N to R.

Overall I did enjoy the game but its just those few problems that took some of the joy out of playing the game. I would give this game a 6.5/10.

reviewText:
I actually don’t recommend RaceRoom Racing Experience BUT...

I took a moment to look through some of the positive and negative reviews prior to writing this and realized some things which actually changed my opinion of the game from the perspective of functional game content.

The one criticism I have which has not changed is the sound. I’m not a professional racer, I don’t know what it sounds like to be behind the wheel of one of these monstrosities, but when I play a racing game with a 5.1 surround system I expect it to feel raw and powerful. Instead, I found all of the vehicles to sound unbelievably anemic and whiny. Again, I have no idea what these cars may sound like in real life, but this is a game. It’s disappointing to see such aggressive speed machines yet hear whiny little RC cars.

Now one of the first things I learn was that this is (at least in some capacity) the same people responsible for Race07. I recently gave that game a whirl and had a nauseatingly terrible experience with it. Whatever they learned from those past titles they have clearly refined it and mastered it for RaceRoom. I know a lot of time has passed between the two, but it’s hard to think this quality sim is from the same people behind Race07. Great job, devs; keep up the iteration and self improvement!

The next thing I took a step back from complaining about was the Free-to-Play model. Many of the negative reviews pointed out the frankly incomprehensible way in which content is being sold. I think the model is confusing and poorly thought out, but I don’t think the fact that you are expected to pay for the majority of the cars when the game and a handful of vehicles are completely free is a point to merit a negative review. The game is extremely detailed and - as best I can tell - extremely faithful to the physics behind circuit racing. RaceRoom isn’t a Free-to-Play racing game in my eyes; it’s a demo for a well crafted racing simulator that allows you to pay for exactly the content you want if you decide that the mechanics interest you.

I didn’t much enjoy it, but RaceRoom Racing Experience is a free demo for a very high quality racing simulator. If you’re into this genre and like what you see in the screenshots, you should absolutely try out the game. There is literally nothing to lose by trying it out.

reviewText: RaceRoom is an excellent racing sim, one of the best actually. It has amazing graphics, physics and sounds. It runs smooth but there's one flaw and it's somewhat big. The real downside of this game is it's purchasing system and expandability. Remember, this game is free, but in reality, it's not. There is a plethora of cars and tracks, however, you only get a very small handful of each as Free to play. And I mean pretty small where I'd be dying to try the cars and tracks that you would need to buy each one separately, which to me is a gimmick.\n\nOverall, RaceRoom is a great game and all, it's just that the developers had incorporated a very ♥♥♥♥♥♥ expansion system. In my sense, I would've rather paid for the game to get all of the features in place of it being free.

reviewText:
Having spent some time around the various racing sims, I can say this is not the most realistic, not the best looking and not the best feeling (Force Feedback) sim out there. But currently it's my favourite,

The game is free, but you have to pay for content like cars and tracks. Considering that you probably will have a few favorite rides and some favourite places to race, you don't need to buy everyting, and with that in mind the pricing is reasonable (just buy a points package and get the content you are interested in). To get everything you have to spend a significant amount of cash, but it's still cheaper than playing iRacing or something like Project CARS / Assetto Corsa with all DLC considering the amoutn of content that is available.

Now for the game itself. The graphics are good, though not mind blowing, but considering that you will be focused on turning that wheel and operating the pedals, you will forget about visuals fast. The sound on the other hand is the best in the market hands down.

Handling is fairly realistic, though not hardcore difficult like rFactor 2, with good Force Feedback once configured properly. Though it is possible to enhoy the game with a controller, a wheel is highly recommended.

Now for the sweet parts - contrary to other sims, there is a good combination of cars and tracks. You will not see stuff like 1 car per class or useless roadcars that go slow and spin out all the time - no Ferraris and SLS AMGs, no drifting. This is all about racing. And racing is good. The AI is one of the better ones, so you will not get divebombed by crazy maniacs all the time, and the difficulty setting will accomodate players of all skill levels. Not the best AI in the market, but quite good and most of all fun,

The bad stuff? No night racing or rain. Not really a big deal, since in other sims these types of races a cool to look at, but mostly hard and frustrating. Perhaps the biggest issue to me is the lack of a dynamic racing line, where the track rubbers up in places where cars drive and you have more grip there. Not really a problem, but once you try something like this in rFactor 2, you do notice it other games. Raceroom also lacks open-wheelers and does not have many classic cars, but that is to change soon. Another thing is a full flag rules system is still to be addes at some point.

All in all, of all the new generation of racing sims, Raceroon seems most fun thanks to a good selection of cars and tracks and good AI. If you are looking to get into simracing this is defo the game to try. Other sims might have better graphics or laser scanned tracks, but not the AI Racerrom has nor the amount of actual racing content we see here.

reviewText: This game has come a long way from the very first time I tried it back in early 2013 and is very solid for a Beta release, it has a lot of potential for a f2p game. The sound is amazing and the physics need just a little improvement. The tracks look amazing and the tracks made by the developer are fun and challenging. My only major critisism is the AI which is a long way in my opinion from being complete, they will ram you time and again if you're on a turn and they accelerate faster than you. The control system could use a little work and be more descriptive on how the sensitivity settings for controller (using a wired Xbox 360 controller until I can afford a descent steeling wheel rig) because after many sessions of tweaking the settings for steering acceleration I am still lost on how the settings affect my controller. Other than that this game is definitely worth a try if you are looking into Racing Sims. 9/10

reviewText: Simple as this:\nI do not like the format much, Pay to Play twists me the wrong way and I would not like to see it re appearing too much andtherefore I do not have a lot of experience with this sim as I would rather pay for something up front, however, I can still say that this is a fantastic sim by Sector 3 Studios and well worth a look, but, for now, whilst I am in the financial deficit I am in, I shall stick to the cheap-and-cheerful Race 07, which is cheaper, just less advanced by this in terms of the same engine (in terms of physics, graphics and sound) and the... not so intelligent Artificial Intelligence, which are MUCH better in RaceRoom.\nOverall, If you are willing to spend a lot, get this game, If not, get another - older - game, which would be cheaper.

reviewText: First of all, I think DTM Experience might be the best racing simulation out there.  I hope that RaceRoom emulates it more and more as I'm sure it will.  Raceroom itself is still in beta and therefore it doesn't have much other than doing practice sessions with AI.  I took advantage of a sale recently and got all RaceRoom content for about $70.  That's a few dozen cars and 15-20 tracks I think.  That's a great price especially compared to another race sim that I've spent about $1,000 on (iRacing).  RaceRoom is a lot of fun.\n\nDTM is a little lacking in content (no pit stops, no rain, no mp) but some of that should come later.  At least I know the multiplayer will.  Even though it's lacking in content it is one very, very good racing simulation.  I highly recommend it.

I took a moment to look through some of the positive and negative reviews prior to writing this and realized some things which actually changed my opinion of the game from the perspective of functional game content.

The one criticism I have which has not changed is the sound. I’m not a professional racer, I don’t know what it sounds like to be behind the wheel of one of these monstrosities, but when I play a racing game with a 5.1 surround system I expect it to feel raw and powerful. Instead, I found all of the vehicles to sound unbelievably anemic and whiny. Again, I have no idea what these cars may sound like in real life, but this is a game. It’s disappointing to see such aggressive speed machines yet hear whiny little RC cars.

Now one of the first things I learn was that this is (at least in some capacity) the same people responsible for Race07. I recently gave that game a whirl and had a nauseatingly terrible experience with it. Whatever they learned from those past titles they have clearly refined it and mastered it for RaceRoom. I know a lot of time has passed between the two, but it’s hard to think this quality sim is from the same people behind Race07. Great job, devs; keep up the iteration and self improvement!

The next thing I took a step back from complaining about was the Free-to-Play model. Many of the negative reviews pointed out the frankly incomprehensible way in which content is being sold. I think the model is confusing and poorly thought out, but I don’t think the fact that you are expected to pay for the majority of the cars when the game and a handful of vehicles are completely free is a point to merit a negative review. The game is extremely detailed and - as best I can tell - extremely faithful to the physics behind circuit racing. RaceRoom isn’t a Free-to-Play racing game in my eyes; it’s a demo for a well crafted racing simulator that allows you to pay for exactly the content you want if you decide that the mechanics interest you.

I didn’t much enjoy it, but RaceRoom Racing Experience is a free demo for a very high quality racing simulator. If you’re into this genre and like what you see in the screenshots, you should absolutely try out the game. There is literally nothing to lose by trying it out.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Pros:

+ Cars drive, feel and look great
+ Amazing sound
+ Good immersion and sense of speed
+ Amount of quality content
+ Test drive all cars before buying
+ Free competitions with the possibility to try out a big variation of content
+ Comes with 2 free tracks and a few cars
+ Solid netcode and fun multiplayer
+ Gamepad support

Cons:

- Obscure payment model with in-game virtual currency and microtransactions
- Overpriced content (even with the regular discounts)
- Not much going on in multiplayer. For paid content it's even worse.
- The vast amount of microtransactions split the small public multiplayer community even further.

Conclusion:

This could be one of the most fun and populated racing sims out there if not for the publishers greedy payment/business model. Actually I like the idea to only pay for the content I want. Buy all tracks and your favourite cars of the series you want to race in and you're all set. But in reality the way it is now it doesn't work out. The pricing is not clear and fair enough. The public multiplayer community is split and barely alive. There is not enough going on online to justify buying the content. I was torn between giving the game a thumbs up or down. But from my personal point of view it all comes down to the questionable business model imposed by the publisher which keeps the game from being populated and more successful. In the current state I simply cannot recommend it to someone who likes to race online a lot.

reviewText:
It takes a little dedication to get used to the game.
The handling is sometimes a little quirky, especially when new to the game.
Though, when figuring out how the steering exactly works, and lap times are going down, the game really stimulates you to continue - whether on the same track, in the same car, or in the same competition.

I didn't buy any vRP (currency) yet, so I haven't bought any new cars or tracks, but already, I managed to spend over 20 hours into the game. And I don't play games that much, so for me, that's a lot ;)

If racing is really something you enjoy, I would recommend you check it out. Probably, a lot of you will ragequit out, because the handling is a thing to get used to. However, with a little bit of practice, even the 2 free tracks are good to drive on, and even when experienced, those tracks are great fun, and still full of challenge.

Nevertheless, if racing is not your type of game, this might not appeal to you fully.
